Comment: Governor? Fine. President? No. I voted for her and I would again in the general, but no. And I think she should expect to get destroyed in the primary. Not because that’s best for the party or the country but only because the loss devastated morale.  There was a report leading up to 2020 that Bernie was saying that he didn’t think America would vote for a woman President to Elizabeth Warren. I’m unfortunately inclined to agree with him, despite what a militant feminist I am. I would gladly vote for a woman to lead the ticket and the party and the country and the world. But I’m now of the opinion (backed up by facts) that America prefers rapists to women… So we may be stuck trying to educate the masses first. I’d love to be proven wrong on that, but… I’m righteously indignant and I think a majority of present-day America unfortunately only recognizes white men to be able to lead. The propaganda worked, unfortunately.

Comment: 3 things   - If Warren had dropped out prior to Super Tuesday, Bernie would've likely won the nomination in 2020. - Kamala Harris and Hillary Clinton were uninspiring candidates that both felt like they were foisted on voters, not picked by them, pushing moderate views. Harris championed her Republican support, cannibalizing some leftist support, and given the absolute layup of a question "what would you do differently than Biden" said "nothing" not once but TWICE - the second time on Fox News, which would've been an excellent platform to swing the missing voters. - Kamala Harris and Hillary Clinton lost their elections, but if ~70k votes had gone differently in the swing states for Clinton or if ~116k had gone differently for Harris, they'd have won (even though Harris would've still lost the popular vote).   There is a formula for victory. Yes, being a woman has a studied inherent challenge. Boston U estimates a 1-3% automatic hit for just being a woman. But when Biden's win really came down to both the national negative mood to Trump as an incumbent in 2020 combined with the fact that if just ~47k votes had flipped in the swings that Trump would've still won, you can come to see that there's more than just being a woman that caused these two losses. I'm deeply confident that if not for COVID, Trump would've won reelection (losing the popular vote by much less too). The anti-incumbent, reactionary inflation fear that affected voting attitudes globally last year cannot be ignored for contributing to Trump's victory.    If there's a woman as the next nominee - and there doesn't have to be, but if there is because they are the fair winner of a primary - they need to be someone who's consistent, inspiring, and whose policy proposals actually sound like they'll fix problems and not just put tape over them. They'll have extra wind in their sails if 2028 is somehow a fair election given what Trump is doing.   e: grammar in point 2
